WebVR app using A-Frame 1.7.1. draw a pyramid.
Make sure everything is in a single HTML file with embedded CSS and JS in a single code block to be used as a web app.

Certainly! Below is an example of a simple WebVR app using A-Frame version 1.7.1 that draws a pyramid. The code is all within a single HTML file, including embedded CSS and JavaScript.

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Pyramid in A-Frame</title>
    <script src="https://aframe.io/releases/1.7.1/aframe.min.js"></script>
    <style>
        body {
            margin: 0;
            font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, sans-serif;
            height: 100vh;
            display: flex;
            justify-content: center;
            align-items: center;
            background-color: #cccccc; /* Light gray background */
        }
        a-scene {
            width: 100%;
            height: 100%;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>
    <a-scene>
        <a-sky color="lightblue"></a-sky>

        <!-- Draw a pyramid using a custom geometry -->
        <a-entity position="0 1.5 -5">
            <a-cone color="#FFD700" height="2" radius-bottom="1.5" radius-top="0" rotation="-90 0 0"></a-cone>
            <a-box position="0 2.5 0" color="#B22222" depth="1.5" height="0.1" width="1.5"></a-box>
        </a-entity>

        <!-- Add a light source -->
        <a-light type="ambient" color="#ffffff" intensity="0.5"></a-light>
        <a-light type="directional" position="-1 3 1" intensity="0.5"></a-light>

        <!-- Camera -->
        <a-entity camera look-controls position="0 1.6 0"></a-entity>
    </a-scene>
</body>
</html>
```

### Explanation:
- **A-Frame**: A-Frame is a web framework that makes it easy to create VR experiences. The version used here is 1.7.1.
- **Sky**: The `a-sky` element is used to create a blue sky background.
- **Pyramid**: The pyramid is created using an `a-cone` for the peak and an `a-box` for the base. The cone is rotated to stand on its base.
- **Lighting**: Ambient and directional lights are included to illuminate the scene.
- **Camera**: The camera is positioned at (0, 1.6, 0) and is set to look around with the `look-controls`.

You can copy this entire code block to an HTML file and open it in a compatible browser to view the pyramid in VR. Make sure to use a web server (like `http-server` or `Live Server`) to serve the file if you want to use WebXR features.

WebVR app make it a hexagon.
Make sure everything is kept in a single HTML file with embedded CSS and JS in a single code block to be used as a web app.

Certainly! Below is a simple WebVR app using A-Frame that creates a hexagon. The code is contained within a single HTML file, including embedded CSS and JavaScript.

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Hexagon in A-Frame</title>
    <script src="https://aframe.io/releases/1.7.1/aframe.min.js"></script>
    <style>
        body {
            margin: 0;
            font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, sans-serif;
            height: 100vh;
            display: flex;
            justify-content: center;
            align-items: center;
            background-color: #cccccc; /* Light gray background */
        }
        a-scene {
            width: 100%;
            height: 100%;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>
    <a-scene>
        <a-sky color="lightblue"></a-sky>

        <!-- Draw a hexagon using six planes -->
        <a-entity position="0 1 -5" rotation="0 0 0">
            <a-plane position="0 0 0" rotation="0 0 0" width="2.5" height="2.5" color="#FF5733" rotation="0 0 0" side="double"></a-plane>
            <a-plane position="1.25 0 0" rotation="0 60 0" width="2.5" height="2.5" color="#33FF57" side="double"></a-plane>
            <a-plane position="1.25 0 1.25" rotation="0 120 0" width="2.5" height="2.5" color="#3357FF" side="double"></a-plane>
            <a-plane position="0 0 2.5" rotation="0 180 0" width="2.5" height="2.5" color="#FF33A1" side="double"></a-plane>
            <a-plane position="-1.25 0 1.25" rotation="0 -120 0" width="2.5" height="2.5" color="#FF33FF" side="double"></a-plane>
            <a-plane position="-1.25 0 0" rotation="0 -60 0" width="2.5" height="2.5" color="#A1FF33" side="double"></a-plane>
        </a-entity>

        <!-- Add a light source -->
        <a-light type="ambient" color="#ffffff" intensity="0.5"></a-light>
        <a-light type="directional" position="-1 3 1" intensity="0.5"></a-light>

        <!-- Camera -->
        <a-entity camera look-controls position="0 1.6 0"></a-entity>
    </a-scene>
</body>
</html>
```

### Explanation:
- **Hexagon Creation**: The hexagon is approximated by creating six planes that are placed and rotated correctly to form a hexagonal shape. Each plane is a different color.
- **Scene Setup**: The background sky is set to a light blue color.
- **Lighting**: Ambient and directional lighting is used to illuminate the hexagon.
- **Camera**: The camera allows for user control to look around in the scene.

You can copy this entire code block to an HTML file, save it, and then open it in a compatible WebVR browser to view the hexagon. Again, itâ€™s recommended to use a local server to serve the file if you're utilizing WebXR features.
